title: How to Make Easy Fudge

steps.headline: Line a square baking pan with tinfoil and set it aside.
steps.description: You can use an 8-inch or 9-inch (20.32 or 22.86 centimeters) pan. Leave about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) of foil hanging over the edges of the pan. This will make the fudge easier to remove once it's done. You can also use two sheets of wax paper or parchment paper. Lay them down in both directions in the pan so that the bottom and all four sides are covered.

steps.headline: Heat the chocolate chips and condensed milk over low heat until the chocolate has melted.
steps.description: Place a heavy-duty saucepan on the stove and add the chocolate chips and condensed milk. Turn the heat to low wait until the chocolate melts. Stir the mixture often to help the chocolate melt evenly. There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls.

steps.headline: Remove the saucepan from heat and stir in the walnuts and vanilla extract.
steps.description: You can also omit the walnuts, if you wish. The vanilla extract is important because it will help add another layer of sweetness and flavor to the fudge.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into the prepared baking pan.
steps.description: Hold the saucepan over the baking pan, and use a spatula to help guide the mixture into it.

steps.headline: Place the fudge into the fridge and leave it there until it firms up.
steps.description: This will take at least 2 hours depending on the temperature of your fridge. Don't get impatient! The fudge has to be firm before you cut it, or it will make a mess.

steps.headline: Use the tinfoil to remove the fudge from the pan.
steps.description: Once the fudge is firm, grip the edges of the foil like handles, and gently pull the foil out. Set it down onto a sheet of wax paper.

steps.headline: Cut the fudge into smaller pieces.
steps.description: There is enough fudge to make 48 good-sized pieces. You can also cut them into smaller, 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) sized pieces as well.

steps.headline: Serve the fudge on a plate.
steps.description: Cover any leftovers and store them in the fridge. It should last for about 1 week in the fridge.

steps.headline: Prepare your baking pan.
steps.description: Line an 8-inch or 9-inch (20.32 or 22.86 centimeters) square baking pan with wax paper or parchment paper going each direction so that the bottom and all four sides are covered. Leave about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) of wax paper hanging over the edges. This way, you can use them like handles and pull the finished fudge out. You can also do this using tin foil instead.

steps.headline: Heat the condensed milk, chocolate chips, and peanut butter chips in a saucepan over low heat until melted.
steps.description: Stir the ingredients often to help the chips melt evenly. Keep stirring until everything is melted, smooth, and mixed together. There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls. If you do not like peanut butter, you can use another type of chip, such as mint chocolate chip, red velvet chocolate chip, etc.

steps.headline: Remove the saucepan from heat and stir in the vanilla extract and salt.
steps.description: The vanilla will help add a more complex flavor to your fudge. The salt will help cut the sweetness as well as bring out the chocolate and peanut butter flavors.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into the lined pan and refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
steps.description: Use a spatula to help guide the mixture across the bottom of the pan. Once everything is in the pan, place it into the fridge and wait until it becomes firm. The fudge must be firm before you cut it, or you'll end up with an oozy mess.

steps.headline: Remove the fudge from the pan.
steps.description: Once the fudge has hardened up, use the wax paper handles to lift it out of the pan. Peel the wax paper away from the edges.

steps.headline: Cut the fudge into 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) pieces.
steps.description: If the fudge is too hard to cut, let it sit on the kitchen counter for 5 minutes. This will allow it to soften a little. Make sure that you are using a sharp knife to do this.

steps.headline: Serve the fudge on a plate.
steps.description: If there are any leftovers, cover them up and store them in the fridge. The fudge should last about 1 week.

steps.headline: Line a 6-inch or 8-inch (15.24 or 20.32 centimeters) square baking pan with parchment paper.
steps.description: Lay two sheets of parchment paper across the pan going in either direction so that the bottom and all four sides of the pan are covered. Leave about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) of the paper hanging over the edge of the pan so that you can use it to pull the finished fudge out. You can also use wax paper or tinfoil.

steps.headline: Simmer the coconut milk over low to medium-low heat for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Shake the can of coconut milk first before opening it and measuring out the milk. Sometimes, the coconut milk and cream separate, so this will mix them back up again. Stir the milk often while it is simmering so that it doesn't scorch.

steps.headline: Add the chocolate chips and coconut oil and stir with a whisk until they melt.
steps.description: While the coconut oil is not absolutely necessary, it will help the chocolate melt better and give you a smoother, richer fudge in the end. There should be no lumps, clumps, streaks, or swirls.

steps.headline: Remove the pot from heat and stir in the vanilla and salt.
steps.description: The vanilla will lend your fudge a more complex flavor while the salt will help cut the sweetness. It will also help bring out the flavor of the chocolate.

steps.headline: Pour the fudge into the prepared baking pan.
steps.description: If the fudge looks really thin and you suspect that it won't set up, you can add up to 1 cup (175 grams) of melted chocolate chips or some powdered sugar to help firm it up again.

steps.headline: Leave the pan in the fridge for at least 2 hours, preferably overnight.
steps.description: If you are in a rush, you can put it into the freezer for about 30 minutes or until it turns firm. The fudge must be firm before you remove it from the pan and cut it, or it will make an oozy, gloopy mess.

steps.headline: Take the fudge out of the pan and cut it into 1-inch (2.54 centimeters) squares.
steps.description: Use the overhanging parchment paper to lift the fudge out of the pan. Use a sharp knife to cut it into smaller squares.

steps.headline: Serve the fudge.
steps.description: If you have any leftovers, cover them up and store them in the fridge immediately. They should last about1 week.
